New Records: Jake Irvin's 1.16 ERA against the Atlanta Braves is the lowest mark by a pitcher in Nationals history (2005-present) with at least three starts vs. the Braves in a single season.
Key Match Events: Jake Irvin faced the playoff-contending Braves four times in his first full Major League season. The result? A 2-0 record and a 1.16 ERA, punctuated by holding Atlanta hitless for 5 2/3 innings on Wednesday at Nationals Park.
Others: Jake Irvin went six innings, allowing two hits, one run and one walk while striking out five on 84 pitches.
Irvin did not give up a hit until Michael Harris II doubled with two outs in the sixth.
In tandem with catcher Keibert Ruiz, Irvin delivered a pitch mix of 48 four-seam fastballs, 25 sinkers, 10 curveballs and one cutter.
Irvin's fastball reached 96.6 mph and averaged 94.
Irvin established his dominance from the leadoff at-bat by striking out Harris; he then kept the Braves off the bases until he issued a walk to Jorge Soler in the fourth.
Irvin faced the Braves’ order a second time. Ramón Laureano reached first base on a two-out throwing error by CJ Abrams, but Irvin got Sean Murphy to line out to left field to avoid any damage.
Irvin stayed locked in as he faced the Braves’ order a second time.
Irvin had recorded two quick outs in the sixth when Harris came to the plate for the third time.
In a 1-1 count, Irvin delivered a 94 mph fastball in the zone. Harris lined a 109.9 mph double into center field for the Braves’ first hit of the night.
In the next at-bat, Irvin gave up another 1-1 double to center field, this time to Soler, on a 93.9 mph fastball. Harris scored Atlanta’s only run of the game on the 108.6 mph line drive.
With Soler on second base, Irvin bested Ozuna in a seven-pitch at-bat with a strikeout on a 92 mph fastball.
Irvin pumped his fist when Ozuna swung and missed -- he recognized he was done for the night and his 30th start of the season had concluded with a memorable performance.
